name: redisplay
content:
redisplay verb [T often passive]
(IN MUSEUM, ETC.)
Add to word list
Add to word list
to arrange something or a collection of things again in a new place or way so that it can be seen by the public: Redisplaying the exhibits in a flexible, accessible way will embody our commitment to being a modern city. Most of the collection would be re-displayed in another building on the site.
More examplesFewer examplesThe collection will be redisplayed on Oct. 6 after years of storage.They will be working on the sarcophagus before it is re-displayed in a new Ancient Egyptian gallery.The permanent collection will be redisplayed on the first floor.The frieze has been re-displayed in the British Museum.

redisplay verb [T often passive]
(ON SCREEN)
to show words, pictures, etc. again for a second, third, etc. time on a screen: If you have lost the task bar, just press Ctrl-Esc to redisplay it. Click here to re-display the list of houses to allow you to select another house.
More examplesFewer examplesThe error bars from these graphs are redisplayed on each of the three graphs below it.If an unknown code is entered, the prompt will be re-displayed.Often the search string will be redisplayed on the result page to indicate what was searched for.

redisplay noun
(IN MUSEUM, ETC.)
[ S or U ] the act of arranging something or a collection of things again in a new place or way so that it can be seen by the public: A redisplay has been forced on English Heritage by the buildingconstruction work. The committee have been consulted over the redisplay of the existing porcelain collection.
More examplesFewer examplesSeveral exhibits await redisplay in a second room now being prepared.He paid £2 million for a lavish re-display of the world-famous collection.They have invested in the repair and redisplay of damaged material in the National Museum.
